baseline_groups.claim_summary: Effect of showing Black victims on actual giving among white respondents
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Randomly assigned photo of Black hurricane victims
baseline_groups.notes: Not statistically significant at conventional levels. The paper notes this result is insignificant.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Effect of showing Black victims on hypothetical giving among white respondents
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Randomly assigned photo of Black hurricane victims
baseline_groups.notes: Not statistically significant. Consistent null across all specifications.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Effect of showing Black victims on charity support among white respondents
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Subjective support for charitable aid (1-7 scale)
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Randomly assigned photo of Black hurricane victims
baseline_groups.notes: Not statistically significant at 5% level. Marginally significant in some extended control specifications.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Effect of showing Black victims on government support among white respondents
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Subjective support for government aid (1-7 scale)
baseline_groups.treatment_concept: Randomly assigned photo of Black hurricane victims
baseline_groups.notes: Statistically significant at 5%. Most robust of the four outcomes. Significant across most control and sample variations.

global_notes: All four baseline groups match the surface definition. No changes to baseline-group assignments. The paper's key finding is primarily about G4 (government support), which is the only statistically significant result. G1-G3 show negative but insignificant effects. The specification search confirms this pattern: G4 is robust to most variations while G1-G3 remain consistently insignificant.
